title: 107_hr3172
content: The "Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001" provides state sales tax relief for consumers. The Secretary of the Treasury will reimburse eligible States for uncollected state sales tax on tangible personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001, provided certain conditions are met. The Secretary of the Treasury will reimburse eligible States for uncollected state sales tax on tangible personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001. To be eligible, a State must not collect sales tax during this period and comply with the requirements of the Act. The Director of Management and Budget must certify the amount and recommend reimbursement. The Treasury will make an advance payment to each eligible State equal to 80% of the annual average sales tax collected on taxable tangible personal property. The State will pay taxable tangible personal property for the taxable period in 1998, 1999, and 2000, with adjustments for overpayment or underpayment to conform to the required amount. SEC. 3. NEW YORK CITY SALES TAX RELIEF FOR CONSUMERS. The Secretary of the Treasury will reimburse New York City for uncollected municipal sales tax on taxable personal property from November 23, 2001, to December 2, 2001. The reimbursement is subject to conditions set by the Mayor and Director of Management and Budget. The Director of Management and Budget certifies the reimbursement amount recommended by subsection (a). To be eligible for reimbursement, New York City must not collect sales tax on certain items and comply with the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury will make an advance payment to the Mayor of New York City, equal to 80% of the average annual sales tax collected by the city. The city must adjust the sales tax collected on taxable personal property in 1998-2000 to conform to the required amount under subsection (a). SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "sales tax" in this Act refers to a tax on retail sales of tangible property, including a use tax and the Illinois Retailers' Occupation Tax. The term "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The term "use tax" refers to a tax imposed on the storage, use, or consumption of tangible property not subject to sales tax during the taxable period from November 23 to December 2 in the District of Columbia or Puerto Rico.
